question: What practice teaches you to love small losses?
answer:
I think it’s the practice of being present. When we’re not present, we are always looking for something else that will make us happy or give us a sense of fulfillment.
I’ve been practicing this for years and it has helped me tremendously in my life. It’s also one of the reasons why I’m so passionate about helping others learn how to be more present as well.
The other day I was talking with someone who had just lost their job and they were feeling really down. They said “I don’t know what to do now.” And I told them that if they could just take a deep breath and relax, then everything would be okay.
They looked at me like I was crazy but after a few minutes they started to feel better. So I asked them what happened when they took a deep breath? They said “It felt good.”
That’s exactly what happens when we take a moment to be present. We can’t control our thoughts or feelings but we can choose to be aware of them. That awareness is what makes us human.
When we’re not present, we’re always looking for something else that will make us happy or give us a sense of fulfillment. But when we’re present, we realize that there’s nothing wrong with us. There’s no need to try to change anything because everything is already perfect just the way it is.
So next time you find yourself feeling overwhelmed by your circumstances, remember that you have all the power within you to create whatever you want out of life. You just need to be willing to let go of the things that aren’t working for you anymore and embrace the ones that are.

question: How do you make discipline automatic so willpower is spared for thinking?
answer:
I think the answer to this question lies in understanding how our brains work. We are not born with a set of rules that governs our behavior, we learn them as we grow up. The way we learn these rules is through trial and error. When we encounter something new or different, we have to figure out what it means and then act accordingly.
This process can be very difficult when we are faced with situations where there is no clear right or wrong answer. For example, if someone asks us to do something that goes against our values or beliefs, we may feel uncomfortable or unsure about what to do. In order to overcome this feeling, we need to develop a set of rules that guide our behavior in these types of situations.
One way to do this is by using positive reinforcement. Positive reinforcement involves rewarding good behavior with something pleasant (such as a treat) or giving someone else something they want (such as praise). This type of reward system helps us to form habits that lead to better outcomes over time.
Another way to develop good habits is through self-talk. Self-talk refers to the thoughts we have about ourselves and others while we are doing something. By focusing on positive things like “I am capable” instead of negative ones such as “I’m not smart enough”, we can start forming new patterns of thought which will eventually become part of our daily routine.
In conclusion, developing good habits requires practice but also having an understanding of how our brain works so that we know exactly what kind of information needs to be processed before making decisions about whether or not to follow through with certain actions. With this knowledge combined with positive reinforcement techniques like rewards and self-talk, anyone can create lasting changes within themselves!
